title: Water Burial
intro: In this programme, Neil and Dan discuss how water burial could be the efficient and environmentally friendly way to bury the dead in the future. And they teach you six items of useful vocabulary
this_week_question: On average, how many people die each hour?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a hole in the earth where a body is placed
something artificial put into the body

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English – the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and six new items of vocabulary. I'm Dan…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. In this episode we'll be discussing water burial.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes. It’s a bit of a bleak subject, I’m afraid.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Something which is bleak is unpleasant or without hope.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And, do you know what’s really bleak ? It’s this week's question. On average, how many people die each hour?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I am going to guess b) sixty thousand

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And we'll find out if you're right or not at the end of this show. So, the actual figure is 55m people each year. Now, religious or not, there is a practical issue to be dealt with, which is, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What to do with the body? Dan Exactly! So what are the options for the average person?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, there’s burial, or there’s cremation.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Burial is when a body is put into the earth and cremation is when a body is burnt. But there are big problems with both. For example, what two things do most people need in order to be buried?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, a coffin – or a box to put the body in and a grave . That’s the place the coffin and body go into.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Exactly, but coffins are most often made of wood. In the US they use four million acres of forest every year just to make coffins. And as for graves , cemeteries are beginning to get overcrowded – there’s no space left! After all, dying is not exactly a new thing! It’s been happening for years.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Aha, but with cremation, there’s no space needed. And they burn gas to dispose of the body. That’s got to be better. Dan You’d think so, but no. I’ll let Sahar Zand, reporter for the BBC, explain why.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Sahar Zand, BBC reporter During the process, a number of toxins can be emitted into our environment, including mercury from dental fillings. Cremation also has a carbon cost. With the energy used to process one body, you could actually heat a home for the best part of a week in winter

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So cremation can release toxins , or poisons, into the environment and it comes with a very high energy cost – enough to heat a home for almost a week! OK. I can see a smug look in your eye, Dan. What do you have up your sleeve?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It’s the latest thing. Water burial.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Water burial?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: This is where the body is put into an alkali solution and heated to 150 degrees centigrade. This breaks down the tissue and leaves only the skeleton.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Interesting.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes! It has huge advantages over cremation

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Such as?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well for one thing, it takes only 4 hours to finish. It follows the same process as when a body decomposes , but quicker.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When something decomposes it breaks down and decays. Ok, anything else?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It uses much less energy. Each body is weighed and then the computer calculates exactly how much of everything is needed.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ok, it’s more efficient too. Why are you smiling?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: This is the best part! Listen to Sahar again.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Sahar Zand, BBC reporter All that’s left at this point is a brittle skeleton and any artificial implants that they may have had in their body – and they come out almost as good as new. There’s even talk of sending the implants to the developing world, where they can benefit populations that don’t have access to them, because they’re very expensive.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So after the process you have a brittle, or easy to break, skeleton and any implants that they had inside them.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Implants are artificial additions to the body, such as plastic hips or an artificial heart. And they’re clean! They can be recycled and given to someone who needs them! Isn’t that cool?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, what happens to the skeleton?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It gets ground up into dust and put in a jar to give to the family – exactly the same as a traditional cremation. I love it! Sign me up! Would you like to give it a shot?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I can’t answer that question. But can I have the answer to our quiz question?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Of course. I asked: On average, how many people die each hour?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I said b) sixty thousand

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And you, my friend, are dead in the water. Unfortunately, it’s a) six thousand

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ok. Well that’s probably better, isn’t it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes. Neil Shall we have a look at the vocabulary then?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Certainly. Our first word was bleak meaning something unhappy, unpleasant or without hope. What types of things do we typically describe as bleak, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, the weather in the UK can be bleak. It’s very, very dark in the winter. Next we had grave . A grave is a hole in the earth where a body is placed. However, there is another use.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes. We can talk about a situation being grave . The outbreak of war is a very grave situation for many people. Then we had toxin . A toxin is a substance which is poisonous. Have you ever been poisoned by a toxin, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I suppose so, yes. I’ve had food poisoning and that’s caused by toxins .  After that was decompose . When something decomposes , it breaks down and decays. Much like when fruit goes bad and turns black and then becomes liquid.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Then we had brittle . Something which is brittle is easily broken. For example, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Glass, crockery, tiles and some plastic. Crisps! And finally we had implant . An implant is something artificial which has been put into the body – such as an artificial heart or a replacement hip. Would you like to have any implants, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I’d quite like robotic legs. Then I could run faster than anyone!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we’ve run out of time, so that’s the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And we are on social media too - Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube. See you there.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
